entry.title: 🟡 Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt 🔨🪙 ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‌

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text.

You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in August
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in August

Another month with two nice new release deliveries ✨

Learn more in my short top features video in August 2025 on YouTube 📺

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

 

 

My top features in August

 

Transformation Flow: Processing in Batches

You can now break down large transformation flow datasets into batches to avoid out-of-memory (OOM) errors when using the SAP HANA runtime in Datasphere. Defining batches on transformation flows enhances the performance and reliability, while ensuring efficient data integration and processing.

You find this feature in the data integration monitor as it is part of the runtime settings under the Batches tab. Simply pick a suitable column and define the batch sizes in number or records. You can also define to use it only for a large initial load or both initial and delta loads.

➡️  More information.

 

New source and targets for Replication Flows

Microsoft OneLake as a Source for Your Replication Flow

You can now use Microsoft OneLake—which was formerly also known as Azure Data Lake Generation 2—, and the corresponding connection type to add sources to replication flows and replicate data in CSV format from the source for initial loads.

➡️  More information.

  • Cloud Storage Provider Sources
  • Microsoft OneLake Connections

 

SAP Signavio as Target for Your Replication Flows

You can now use connection type SAP Signavio and replication flows to load data from SAP source systems, such as SAP S/4HANA and others, into SAP Signavio as target system. This allows an efficient and scalable data replication into the SAP Signavio solution.

➡️  More information.

  • SAP Signavio Targets
  • SAP Signavio Connections

 

SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel

There is a very nice feature new in SAP Analytics Cloud, which I think is super useful for many of you. With the QRC 3 release, you can transfer a table from an SAC story to Excel and further use it with the add-in. In Excel, the transferred table is based on the same data source, for example Datasphere, and has the same navigation state (dimensions, measures in rows and columns, filters, and variables). The idea is to benefit from native Excel capabilities on Datasphere data in real time. You can adjust the report, add custom functions on top of the table, and more.

➡️  More information.

 



SAP Business Data Cloud Getting Started Series

 

Starting September 10, the Getting Started Series kicks off with three modules

  • Module 1: Build an Intelligent Application Grounded in Data Products (Sep 10, 2025)
  • Module 2: Fuel AI Innovation with SAP Databricks in Business Data Cloud (Sep 24, 2025)

entry.title: SAP BTP now available on Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces
entry.content:
At Sapphire Orlando 2025, we announced SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) availability through Hyperscaler Marketplaces.  I’m happy to share that SAP BTP services are now available for purchase through Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services (AWS), and Google Cloud Marketplaces in the United States. 

Why SAP BTP?   

SAP BTP is SAP’s platform for all SAP applications with over 33,000 customers, 3,000 partners, and 10,000 pre-built accelerators.  It empowers customers and partners with generative AI-powered development, automation, integration, data, and analytics across SAP and non-SAP applications, business processes, and beyond. Accelerate time to value with pre-built workflows and integrations across Finance, HR, Supply Chain, Procurement and more. Empower developers of all skills with tools and languages of their choice, and purpose-built frameworks for business application development. Leverage generative AI capabilities specialized in automating and extending mission-critical business processes.

 

 Here are the key benefits for purchasing SAP BTP through Hyperscaler Marketplaces: 

1. Maximize Cost Efficiency with Existing Cloud Commitments 

Existing customers of Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud can use their committed spend agreements to purchase SAP BTP through their respective cloud marketplaces. The ability to channel unused commitments toward SAP BTP investments allows customers to optimize their budgets and drive more value from their relationships with the Hyperscaler providers. Customers gain greater financial flexibility and can ensure that every dollar spent accelerates their digital transformation initiatives. 

2. Accelerated Procurement and Deployment 

Existing customers are familiar with the purchasing process through their Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud hyperscaler marketplaces, making it easy for them to discover, select, and purchase SAP BTP services in one centralized platform. SAP BTP can then be deployed directly on hyperscaler infrastructure that customers already have in place and rely on for scalability, security, and innovation. This process allows for accelerated procurement and deployment, meaning customers can start innovating with SAP BTP services faster than ever!   

3. Simplified Billing and Vendor Consolidation 

Through Microsoft Azure, AWS, and Google Cloud Marketplaces, customers receive consolidated billing and invoicing that allows them to manage all their hyperscaler cloud services in one place. This enables customers to have better visibility into their spend management, streamline administrative tasks, and ensure compliance with corporate procurement policies. It also reduces the complexity of managing different vendors. 

 

Get Started Today 

Customers in the Uinted States (US) now have the ability to purchase SAP BTP through the hyperscaler marketplaces and the flexibility to run SAP BTP services in their hyperscaler of choice. This reflects SAP’s vision for openness and flexibility and gives our customers the ability to integrate, extend, and innovate their SAP and non-SAP applications.   

To begin your SAP BTP journey, visit the Microsoft Azure, Amazon Web Services, or Google Cloud marketplaces for more information or get in touch with your SAP BTP specialist.  Whether you're looking to move, optimize, or innovate your SAP applications, or create new AI and data-driven experiences, we are ready to help you accelerate your transformation with SAP BTP!

entry.title: Introducing SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4
entry.content:
Exploring the SAP BTP Guidance Framework - Extensibility

I am pleased to announce the availability of the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4. In this blog post, I would like to provide a quick overview and highlight the changes in this newest release.

For a quick introduction to the methodology, please take a look here: SAP Application Extension Methodology.

This blog post is part of the series SAP BTP Guidance Framework: A Compass for Architects, Developers, and Administrators.

The SAP BTP Guidance Framework is a practical framework tailored to anyone using the SAP Business Technology Platform. SAP BTP acts as the technological backbone for building, integrating, extending, and innovating with SAP solutions. Whether you're an enterprise architect, software developer, or administrator, SAP BTP offers significant opportunities for productivity and development.

 

What’s New for SAP Application Extension Methodology

With the SAP Application Extension Methodology version 2.4, we have made some changes to the Extension Technology Mapping. We now include the Clean Core Level concept directly in the Mapping, allowing you to easily follow the latest guidance. Next to each Technical Extension Building Block, you can find the corresponding Clean Core Level (A-D).

SAP Application Extension Methodology - Extension Technology Mapping with Clean Core Levels

Please be aware that the single source of truth for the Clean Core Levels is the official SAP Note 3578329. 

If you are still using an older version of the Technology Mapping, I highly recommend checking out our new version and to learn about the latest innovations and technologies on SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform.

 

Clean Core Level Concept in a Nutshell

Clean Core Levels Overview

TL;DR

  • Always develop your extension with the highest clean core level.
  • Leverage released APIs and best practice classic APIs of Level A and B to be clean core compliant.
  • Avoid not recommended SAP objects of Level D as they are not clean core compliant.

Level A

Level A is considered clean core and your strategic direction. You develop extension with SAP Build either on-stack on SAP S/4HANA and/or Side-by-Side on SAP BTP. Usually, you use a combination of both. You will use ABAP Cloud, CAP and our low-code/no-code tools in SAP Build. You can find the released APIs and extensions points on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Level B

Level B is considered clean core. You use upgrade stable classic APIs, which you can find in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = classic API.

Level C

Level C is considered conditionally clean. Use the internal SAP objects only if needed. There is no guarantee on long-term stability. Apply the changelog for SAP objects to mitigate upgrade risks.

Level D

Level D is considered NOT clean core. Those objects are unfit for customer use. You can find them in the cloudification repository viewer with filter state = noAPI.

 

Next Steps:

Learn more about the SAP Application Extension Methodology on the SAP Help Portal.

Learn more about the SAP BTP Guidance Framework on the SAP Discovery Center and look out for the continuation of the blog post series. The next one will be about Data&Analytics.

Learn more about Clean Core by reading our detailed whitepaper, or tune into our latest Unlocking SAP BTP podcast episode focusing on clean core.

Feel free to like, comment and ask your questions!

Talk to you soon,
Marco

Product Manager SAP Business Technology Platform

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Reference Architecture for Event-Driven Application in Missing Part Fulfilment Busine
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of Industry 4.0, the ability to respond to real-time events in industrial production is crucial for operational efficiency. This blog outlines a proof of concept (PoC) that demonstrates how Airbus leveraged SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP Build Process Automation (BPA), and Events-to-Business Actions Framework to automate and orchestrate the missing part fulfillment process within production operations. The solution leverages an event-driven architecture to automate business processes based on missing part fulfillment in real-time.

This architecture is highly repeatable and can be applied to a wide range of SAP scenarios such as plant maintenance, purchase requisitions, inventory updates, and more, making it a valuable reference for enterprises looking to scale event-driven integrations. 

Engagement

The outcome described in this article was facilitated by custom adaptation of the Events-to-Business-Actions Framework by Airbus and was supported by SAP OCTO Team under PVN Pavankumar

Business Scenario : Missing Part Fulfilment in Production

The use case centres on streamlining the missing part fulfilment process within Airbus production operations. It begins when a missing part is detected for a work order reservation in the SAP ECC backend, which supports day-to-day production activities. From that initial identification, the process continues all the way through to the confirmation of the work order operation.

Throughout this journey, the workflow leverages an event-driven architecture (EDA) to track progress in real time, integrating seamlessly with backend systems. SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) orchestrates collaboration between all involved actors by sending out forms and notifications, gathering approvals, and automating decisions based on predefined business rules. Additionally, the PoC highlights the real-time monitoring and dashboarding features of SAP Build Process Automation, ensuring end-to-end visibility across the process.

This PoC showcases how we made that happen. 

Solution Architecture

Below is the architecture diagram representing the technical landscape for the missing part fulfilment process.

Figure 1: End-to-end architecture of the Airbus missing part fulfillment solution using SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, E2B Framework, and custom Node.js applications.

Technical Implementation 

This architecture leverages key components across SAP BTP, Advanced Event Mesh, and custom applications to create a robust event-to-action pipeline: The Solution Architecture is illustrated in Figure 1, and the important components along with their connectivity are explained below:

-> Business events are triggered:
Different actors interact with the SAP backend (supporting production operations). Transactions such as work order reservations, purchase orders, or outbound deliveries generate relevant business events.

-> Events are routed to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM):
These events are sent to SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh—either directly or via Solace event brokers in Airbus Private Cloud, especially if events need to be shared with other platforms.

->  Event-specific queues manage the flow:
Within SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, specific queues collect events related to predefined topics, pushing them into the Events to Business Actions (E2B) framework.

->  Business logic and workflows are triggered:
E2B calls SAP Build Process Automation (BPA) APIs to:

  • Apply decision rules and determine what business action should occur based on the event payload,
  • Launch new workflow instances,
  • Update waiting tasks on running workflows,
  • Push events to visibility scenarios for process monitoring.

->  Backend queries for richer context:
E2B also calls backend APIs to fetch more information related to business objects—such as:

  • Details of a reservation linked to a purchase order,
  • The specific station tied to a work order reservation,
  • The list of actors involved, leveraging Responsibility Management in SAP S/4HANA based on attributes like station.

->  Traceability with PartsNow:
PartsNow, is a custom SAP Cloud Application Programming (CAP,Node.js) application, used to persist the relationship between workflow instance IDs and related work order reservation IDs. E2B registers new workflow instances and can retrieve instance details as needed via PartsNow APIs.

->  Unified user experience in SAP Build Workzone:
SAP Build Workzone serves as the entry point for business actors, providing:

  • My Inbox: For completing tasks such as form fills or approvals,
  • My Processes: For real-time workflow monitoring,
  • Process Visibility Dashboard: To track KPIs and process efficiency,
  • Studio Home: Where process specialists can manage BPA decision rules.

->  Automated notifications and integration points:
Finally, SAP BPA calls remote APIs to:

  • Inform the PartsNow app about workflow instance completion,
  • Send email notifications to relevant actors via an SMTP server.

 

Developer Insights

As a developer building this PoC, a few key learnings stand out:

  • Loose coupling using SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh and queues ensures resiliency and scalability.
  • Decision capability in SAP Build Process Automation allowed us to externalize complex logic from the app code, making it easier to maintain and extend.
  • Using SAP BTP Destinations and Service Bindings helped standardize secure backend access across environments.

Deployment Steps

Follow this GitHub documentation for detailed steps for configuration and deployment.

 

Closing Remarks

We hope this blog has inspired new ideas for applying event-driven automation to your own business processes.

Refer to SAP Architecture Centre and Events-to-Business-Actions Framework Repository for implementation details. 

Thanks to colleagues from SAP OCTO Team Praveen Kumar Padegal and Swati Maste for their support.

entry.title: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable agentic development for Enterprise Applications
entry.content:
Agentic AI application development is fundamentally reshaping the way business applications are designed, developed, and delivered. AI-powered assistants and copilots are rapidly becoming an integral part of the development process, helping teams to boost productivity, reduce errors, and innovate faster than ever.

Meeting Developers Where They Are

SAP is committed to meeting developers where they’re at – that means no matter where or how you code, you have the freedom to choose the environment that best suits your needs and access to the tools that maximize your productivity and impact.

To that end, I’m excited to share that SAP is introducing Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to boost development with the following technologies:

  1. Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP)
  2. SAP Fiori Elements 
  3. SAPUI5 

By adopting these new MCP standards, developers can seamlessly extend SAP’s development capabilities into multiple environments, ensuring flexibility and choice. SAP Build now enhances popular IDEs and AI coding assistants such as Cursor, Windsurf, Github Copilot, Cline and Claude Code.

We are also excited to share that the MCP Servers are being released as an open-source projects, licensed under the Apache-2.0 license. This marks another step in our commitment to openness and community-driven innovation. Learn more about Open Source at SAP.

What is an MCP?

MCP is an emerging open standard that allows AI models and tools to interact in a structured, secure, and consistent way. MCP acts as a universal bridge between an AI coding assistant with an LLM and external tools, data, and workflows — so the model can seamlessly fetch context, take actions, and deliver more accurate, useful results. MCP gives developers the ability to integrate their tools with the broader AI ecosystem while receiving the right assistance, at the right time, without switching contexts.

The Value of SAP MCP Tools

While many AI tools generate code, SAP takes this a step further by ensuring that what’s generated provides a solid foundation for building enterprise-grade applications. The MCP tools delivered by SAP are backed by our technology teams and designed specifically for SAP Business Applications. This means:

  • Best Practices Built-In: Generated code with CAP, UI5 and Fiori elements code already provides you with the right starting point for reaching SAP standards and proven design guidelines.
  • Guided Development: Developers receive recommendations and guardrails tailored to SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
  • Consistency:  SAP’s MCP tools are and will be reused across our tooling portfolio, ensuring consistent developer experience and outcomes wherever you build SAP applications. Whether you’re generating backend services, UIs, or business logic, you can rely on the same quality, structure, and compliance.

Scaling AI Agents with SAP Expertise

One of the most powerful aspects of MCP adoption is the ability to upscale AI agent chat capabilities with deep SAP application development expertise. This means that AI copilots and agents can go beyond generic code suggestions to provide context-aware, SAP-specific guidance. Whether you are working with Vibe Coding tools on the web or coding directly in your IDE of choice, MCP brings value to everyone — from casual and junior developers to senior professionals. It enables you to build enterprise-grade SAP applications with confidence, while seamlessly combining AI-driven assistance with SAP’s trusted frameworks, best practices, and tooling to maximize productivity.

 

Looking Ahead

These are exciting times to be a developer. The combination of AI and open standards like MCP is rewriting the rules of software development. At SAP, we are committed to keeping our developer community at the forefront of innovation. By investing in AI-powered tools and standards, we ensure that you—our developers—have everything you need to build, scale, and innovate with confidence. 🚀

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #1 in the Series
entry.content:
Organizations around the world are migrating their databases to the cloud, striving to increase operational efficiency, performance, and scalability while reducing costs. But not all databases are created equal.

SAP HANA Cloud is a cloud-native, in-memory database that delivers high performance, scalability, and powerful analytics. It lets you store, process, and query various types of data and models in a single system. Developers can build and deploy intelligent applications, rapidly and at scale. These are just a few of the reasons why so many companies have moved to SAP HANA Cloud.

The value is clear. In a recent study,[1]  IDC found that large enterprises could realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud. This benefit equates to $820,000 per SAP HANA Cloud database per year, with a three-year ROI of 352%. Isn’t that impressive?

The promise of SAP HANA Cloud is attractive for organizations considering a database migration. But you still need to make your business case to justify a modernization initiative.

To help you develop your argument, I’ve created this blog series on the top 10 benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I’ll review some of the key features and capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud and explore how each one can help your organization realize critical business value. Let’s get started.

Multi-model engines

No enterprise relies on only one type of data. Depending on your business, you may be using relational, geospatial, graph, JSON, and vector data, for example. This data can be structured, semi-structured, or unstructured, including text and multimedia content. Some organizations funnel data into single-purpose databases that handle only certain data types. But that database specialization creates additional costs, management effort, and complexity.

SAP HANA Cloud handles diverse workloads within a unified system—processing relational, geospatial, knowledge graph, time series, and vector data for AI applications. This ability to support multi-modal AI, where systems comprehend and process information from various data types, adds versatility. Application developers can integrate diverse data sources into a single application with ease and users can query and blend diverse data types intuitively. Multi-modal AI also reduces the need for complex ETL processes between systems.

entry.title: Introducing Reporting Scope and Data Collection in SAP Sustainability Control Tower
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of the SAP Sustainability Control Tower as of September 1st, 2025.

Why SAP Developed Reporting Scope and Data Collection

SAP introduced the Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature in Sustainability Control Tower (SCT) to address the challenges organizations face when manually collecting sustainability data. Many customers struggled with decentralized, manual processes – often relying on emails and spreadsheets – which made it difficult to ensure data quality, traceability, and compliance with regulatory requirements. The new feature provides an integrated, workflow-based solution that guides users through the process, ensures relevant KPIs are collected, and supports collaboration between central and local teams. 

What Does the Feature Do?

The Reporting Scope and Data Collection feature enables organizations to:

  • Define which sustainability metrics are relevant for reporting.
  • Configure how data should be collected and who is responsible.
  • Guide users through a structured, form-based workflow for data entry, review, and approval.
  • Track and manage data collection runs for different reporting periods.
  • Ensure data is captured, approved, and stored in a traceable manner. 

Step-by-Step Guide: SAP SCT Applications

  1. Manage Reporting Scope
  • Define the scope of sustainability reporting by selecting relevant metrics and organizational boundaries.
  • Set validity dates and add comments for each metric (e.g., materiality, monitoring purposes).
  • Capture the results of double materiality assessments and specify which KPIs require data collection.
  • In this simplified example the organizational boundary is set to Business Region EMEA and the Scope Items are the ESRS items Total energy consumption related to own operations - E1-5 - (37)(AR 35) and Total water consumption - E3-4 - (28a).

  1. Configure Data Collection
  • Assign data processors and approvers for each scoped metric and organizational entity.
  • Choose the data collection method (e.g., workflow-based).
  • Ensure responsibilities are clear for each data point to streamline collaboration

  1. Configure Data Entry
  • Customize the data entry form for each metric, including the data collection cycle (e.g., monthly, quarterly or yearly) and required breakdowns by a master data dimension.
  • Add instructions and enable relevant dimensions to guide processors during data entry

  1. Manage Data Collection Instances
  • Set up data collection runs for specific reporting years and periods.
  • Define start, submission, and approval dates to control the workflow timeline.
  • Generate forms for each reporting period and metric, ensuring timely data collection. 

  1. Manage Data Collection Forms
  • Preview and send out data collection forms to assigned processors.
  • Processors enter data and submit for approval; approvers review, approve, or reject submissions.
  • Approved data is published and stored, with full traceability in SCT. 

 

This new workflow-based approach in SAP SCT streamlines sustainability data collection, improves data quality, and supports compliance with evolving regulatory standards.

Feature status and outlook: Currently, the feature supports quantitative metrics and measures for sustainability reporting. In future iterations, SAP plans to include qualitative metrics and basic custom metrics, as well as additional data entry methods, plausibility checks, multi-step approvals and email notifications based on customer feedback.

For further support, please also visit Data Collection Workflow for Quantitative Metrics | SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP Incentive Management for Real-time Incentive calculation
entry.content:
Integrating SAP Sales Cloud V2 with SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management creates a powerful solution for real-time incentive calculation and sales performance optimization. Here's a breakdown of how this integration works and the benefits it offers:

Integration Overview

The mashup between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP SuccessFactors Incentive Management enables sales teams to:

  • View real-time incentive data directly within the Sales Cloud interface.
  • Access a unified dashboard showing opportunities, leads, commissions, and payouts.
  • Receive instant updates as deals progress, with incentive data refreshed in real time.
  • Gain actionable insights into how performance affects earnings and what actions can maximize incentives.

Key Benefits

  1. Real-Time Insights & Motivation

    • Sales reps can see their commissions and performance metrics instantly.
    • Features like commission estimates, leaderboards, and performance dashboards help boost motivation.

  2. Streamlined Dispute Resolution

    • One-click traceability allows quick resolution of compensation inquiries.
    • Reduces administrative overhead and keeps reps focused on selling.

  3. Optimized Incentive Plans

    • Use AI-driven recommendations to refine compensation strategies.
    • Identify opportunities for bonuses or accelerators to maximize ROI.

  4. Flexible Plan Design

    • Easily model and test complex incentive plans using drag-and-drop tools.
    • Roll out new promotions without heavy IT involvement

Implementation Highlights

  • Once integrated, users can navigate to Sales History → Opportunities in SAP Sales Cloud V2.
  • A new dashboard section appears showing incentives and payments.
  • The mashup is enabled via standard configuration steps provided by SAP.

Integration Flow Description

  1. SAP Sales Cloud V2

    • Opportunity is created and assigned to a Opportunity Owner (Sales Employee).
    • Opportunity data includes total revenue,opporuntiy date, product, and stage.

  2. Employee Sync

    • The Employee in Sales Cloud is synced with SuccessFactors via master data integration.
    • Employee is linked to a Position in Incentive Manager.

  3. SuccessFactors Incentive Management

    • The Position is mapped to an Incentive Plan.
    • Incentive Plan defines rules, rule elements including quotas, accelerators, and payout logic.

  4. Real-Time Calculation

    • As the Opportunity progresses, incentive calculations are triggered.
    • Sales reps can view estimated commissions, performance dashboards, and leaderboards directly in Sales Cloud.

  5. Feedback Loop

    • Incentive results are sent back to Sales Cloud for visibility.
    • Managers can adjust plans or resolve disputes using traceable data.

In my previous blog, I discussed how SAP HANA Cloud delivers critical business benefits to organizations that migrate their database to the cloud. Advanced features such as multi-model engines allow enterprises to increase productivity and reduce complexity. In a recent study,[1]  IDC calculated that large enterprises can realize an annual average value of US$13.7 million by using SAP HANA Cloud.

Understanding how the specific capabilities of the database benefit your organization is key to helping you justify a cloud modernization initiative. Let’s look at two more capabilities that can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud: infrastructure independence and a next-generation application foundation.

Infrastructure independence

Your database requirements constantly evolve. To keep up with changing business conditions, customer requirements, and user demand, you need an infrastructure that matches your needs. A solution that offers vendor independence is key.

SAP HANA Cloud offers multi-cloud flexibility so you can run on your hyperscaler of choice. The cloud-native architecture runs on Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform, Microsoft Azure, Alibaba Cloud, and soon, SAP data centers. You can choose a hyperscaler without fear of vendor lock-in.

 

Because it uses cloud-native technologies, the architecture offers consistent, high performance no matter which provider you choose. Automated failover and recovery features enhance resilience. Database administrators can provision new instances in just minutes. And elastic scaling capabilities respond to changing workload demands in real time.

SAP HANA Cloud also reduces the complexity of database operations. It simplifies integration across hybrid or multi-cloud environments and provides direct access to data in SAP applications. Because SAP HANA Cloud is a fully managed database-as-a-service (DBaaS) from SAP, your IT personnel are free to focus on value-added tasks. What’s more, SAP HANA Cloud covers your database, infrastructure, and management requirements, eliminating the need for a separate infrastructure contract with your hyperscaler.

The IDC study assessed the financial impact of infrastructure independence and the associated flexibility. After deploying SAP HANA Cloud, study participants reported a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams and said that database deployments were executed 38% faster. Considering the costs of IT staff management, unplanned downtime, and database infrastructure, IDC calculated a 35% lower annual total cost of ownership for SAP HANA Cloud over a three-year period.

According to one study participant with a large database environment,

“SAP HANA Cloud has enabled us to redirect IT staff to focus more on the production environment, new development, integration, and leveraging AI. Overall, this allows them to help drive revenue and increase productivity.”

Next-generation application foundation

To gain business value from modern, intelligent applications, you need a sophisticated database that can support multiple data types from various sources, process data in real time, and deliver insightful analytics.

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, an open cloud platform with data management, analytics, AI, IoT, blockchain technologies and application development services. Together, SAP HANA Cloud and SAP BTP form a full-stack solution that includes powerful integration features and an intuitive interface, all under one commercial model.  In addition, SAP HANA Cloud is the trusted database that powers SAP’s mission-critical solutions, such as SAP Business Cloud, with multi-model engines and enterprise-grade performance and reliability.

SAP HANA Cloud also empowers developers to create intelligent applications using today’s most advanced technologies. With this database, teams can build applications that use generative AI, machine learning, and specialized engines to handle vectors, knowledge graphs, property graphs, and spatial processing. It also manages semi-structured JSON data with ACID compliance. The resulting applications are context-aware and offer secure connections to critical business data and curated data products from SAP.

This integrated approach allows applications to ingest and process data in multiple formats and from various sources, including SAP and third-party solutions. Users get live access to critical business information without data replication. Native connectivity to various data sources unifies disparate data streams, offering a single holistic view of your enterprise data. Applications can respond to events in real time, support automated processes, and enable ad-hoc decision-making using current and historical data.

 Having a next-generation application foundation adds IT, performance, and business enablement benefits, according to the IDC study. After adopting SAP HANA Cloud, participating organizations realized a 33% efficiency boost for their infrastructure teams. Query speed and response time increased by 31% and 29%, respectively. Enterprises processed 151% more data sources and 77% greater data volume (in terabytes) than in previous environments. Business operations improved, thanks to enhanced analytics that led to better business decisions, an accelerated application development process, and more agile deployment of database resources. Participants also realized end-user productivity gains of 18%, leading to annual gross revenue gains of nearly $40 million per organization.

A study participant who works in the healthcare industry summarized the value of SAP HANA Cloud.

“SAP HANA Cloud provides my organization the ability to apply parallel processes and maintain scalable databases,” he said. “As a result, we have been able to build a lot of applications with machine learning and AI capabilities. With SAP HANA Cloud, it is easier to integrate these applications.”

entry.title: ‌🎩‌The Magic of Attributes in SAP IAS: Default vs Enrich Assertion
entry.content:
✨🪄 Revellio 🪄✨

                                                                                                      🌟🔮🧙‍♀️🪄✨🧝‍♂️🌟

                                                        “ Unveiling the secrets of Identity Federation, one step at a time…”

✨🧙‍♂️ Unlocking SAP IAS Attribute Magic: Default vs Enrich Secrets Revealed 🎩

About Me

Hare Krishna 🙏 I am an SAP BTP Cloud Architect sharing practical insights, solutions, and real-world experiences from the SAP ecosystem.

🌟Introduction

When integrating SAP SaaS products on BTP, managing user attributes becomes a big challenge. Every app expects something slightly different—from hardcoded values to custom claim names. Without IAS, you'd have to tame these discrepancies in every corporate IdP or app individually, which isn't sustainable.

🔑IAS centralizes this with:

  1. 🟦 Default Attributes

  2. 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes

  3. ⚙️Identity Federation controls which method is applied

📘Concepts: When Which Mechanism Applies

Default vs. Enrich Assertion Attributes

SAP IAS provides two methods to control how attributes are sent to applications:

1. 🟦 Default Attributes

  • Configured at the application level inside IAS.

  • Can be static (hardcoded), pulled from IAS user store, or derived.

  • ✅Used when Identity Federation is enabled.

2. 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes

  • Configured in the corporate IdP connection inside IAS.

  • Uses values from the upstream IdP, with transformation before sending to apps.

  • ✅Used when Identity Federation is disabled.
    (📄 Official Doc)

🔄Identity Federation in IAS

Identity Federation decides whether IAS acts as the authoritative IdP 🆔 or a proxy 🔀:

  • Federation Enabled

    • IAS processes 🟦 Default Attributes.

    • Useful even when using corporate IdP—IAS can inject hardcoded values like Groups = sac.

  • Federation Disabled

    • IAS functions as a pass-through proxy.

    • Only 🟩 Enrich Assertion Attributes are active, customizing only based on the upstream IdP data.
      (📄 Reference)

💡This flexibility ensures SAP SaaS tools always receive what they expect—without demanding changes in your corporate IdP or each app.

🌟How IAS Helps Customers

Setting up SSO for SAP SaaS apps can be tricky—each service has its own attribute requirements. Without IAS, you’d constantly tweak your corporate IdP or each app.

With Default and Enrich Assertion Attributes, IAS provides a centralized layer to standardize attributes once and reuse across apps.

🔑Real-World Scenarios(few examples)

SAP ServiceRequiredHow IAS helps
Datasphere / SAC 📊Groups = sacA retail company can inject this via Default Attribute to authorize analysts without changing Azure AD groups.
Signavio 🟧signavio_groupsA manufacturing firm maps workspace groups via Enrich Assertion when federation is off, or as Default Attribute when federation is on—no IdP restructuring needed.
Kyma Runtime 🌀Groups as groupsA tech startup transforms incoming Group claims from Okta to groups for app provisioning without any code changes.
SAP BTP Services 🔷firstname, lastname, emailA logistics company ensures consistent user attributes from IAS or upstream IdP for automated user provisioning.

💡Customer Value

  • Less Customization: Corporate IdPs remain clean; no per-app hacks.

  • Faster Rollouts: Onboard new SAP tools quickly.

  • Compliance & Governance: Centralized attribute control improves auditability.

  • Flexibility: Hardcode, map, or enrich attributes depending on SaaS needs—without breaking federation.

Whether it’s Datasphere, Signavio, or Kyma, IAS ensures your SSO setup just works, letting IT teams focus on business instead of identity headaches.

⚙️Configuring Attributes in IAS — Step-by-Step

Here’s how to set up each mechanism using the IAS Admin Console 🖥️:

1. 🟦 Configure Default Attributes (for Federation Enabled)

  • Navigate to IAS Admin Console → Applications.

  • Select your application (e.g., 📊 Datasphere).

  • Go to Trust → Assertion Attributes / Default Attributes.

  • Add Default Attribute:

    • Example: Groups = sac (hardcoded value)

    • Or map values: ${user.firstName}, ${user.company}

  • 💾Save and exit.
    (📄 Doc)

2. 🟩 Configure Enrich Assertion Attributes (for Federation Disabled)

  • Go to IAS Admin Console → Identity Providers → Corporate Identity Providers.

  • Select your corporate IdP (e.g., Microsoft Entra ID logo 🔵).

  • Open the Assertion Enrichment tab.

  • Add mapping rules:

    • Example: ${user.email} → emailAddress

    • Example: ${customAttribute1} → employeeNumber

  • 💾Save the configuration.
    (📄 Doc)

3. 🧪 Test and Validate

  • Use IAS’s Test tool 🧰 or a SAML tracer 🔍.

  • Confirm:

    • 🟦 Default Attributes appear with Federation Enabled.

    • 🟩 Enrich mappings appear with Federation Disabled.

📸Real-Life Example (Screenshot Placeholder) 

🏗️ Architecture: IAS as Proxy (OIDC ↔ SAML)

 BTP Application (BAS)
          │  (OIDC)
          ▼
   ┌──────────────────────────────┐
   │           SAP IAS            │
   │  ┌────────────────────────┐  │
   │  │   Application Side     │◄─┼─ Identity Federation Enabled
   │  │   (Default Attributes) │  │
   │  └────────────────────────┘  │
   │                              │
   │  ┌────────────────────────┐  │
   │  │ Corporate IdP Side     │◄─┼─ Identity Federation Disabled
   │  │ (Enrich Assertion Attr)│  │
   │  └────────────────────────┘  │
   └──────────────────────────────┘
          │  (SAML)
          ▼
   Corporate Identity Provider

Step-by-Step Explanation for Different Scenarios

Scenario 1: Enhancement of attributes coming from Identity provider.

Without Identity Federation Enabled

Users in IAS (user which we will use don't exist in IAS)

Identity fedration is disabled

And Enrich assertion attributes are not set. Expectation is - IAS should direct the Attributes coming from IDP to SAP BTP application(BAS in our scenario)

Perform Login Process to generate Assertion(from IDP) and JWT token(from IAS).

Enter Corporate IDP credentials -  User: idpuser@test.com

Login Successful to SAP BTP Application

In SAML assertion from IDP we can see - Groups are coming as part of SAML assertion.

When checked in Troubleshooting logs in IAS - We can see the same attributes.

Now in Corporate IDP - Enrich assertion attributes - to send Groups as Hogwarts_Groups to BTP application. In this scenario - Groups will be sent packaged as Hogwarts_Groups to Application which can be used for specific scenarios.

When we login - we can check in troubleshooting logs of IAS that expected attributes are sent.

Now when we enable Identity Fedration

Enable identity fedration - in corporate IDP -> identity fedration.

Now Enrich assertion attributes in Corporate IDP don't work - we will need to use another functionality called Default attributes in Applications in IAS. In below screenshot we can see that it didn't send any IDP attributes.

Now Setup Default attributes in IAS application as shown in below screenshot - make sure you select corporate IDP in drop down menu to send the attributes from Corporate IDP

Perform login to Application again

Now expected attributes are received by BTP application

Scenario 2: Sending Hardcoded values to Applications using IAS

When Identity Fedration is disabled

Perform it in Corporate IDP -> Enrich assertion attributes

Post successful login - we can check Hard coded values are sent to Application

Identity fedration enabled

IAS application -> Default Attributes -> Set Attrubtes

Post successful login - we can check that Hard coded values are sent to BTP application

🚀Why It Matters

  • 🔗Centralization: Handle diverse SAP SaaS attribute needs from one place.

  • 📈Scalability: Onboard new services without remapping custom attributes everywhere.

  • 🛠️ Maintainability: If tools change, update once in IAS—not in 5 different places.

Whether you’re setting up Datasphere 📊, Signavio 🟧, Kyma 🌀, or other BTP tools, IAS gives you a clean, unified way to tailor attributes—without touching your corporate IdP or apps.

entry.title: Why People Come Before Process and Technology in the SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
When people talk about SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) or any transformation project, the conversation often begins with technology—data models, extensions, integrations, and AI. But in my experience, the real magic of BTP doesn’t just come from its capabilities; it comes from the people who gather around it.

A platform becomes powerful when it inspires collaboration. That’s where community building comes in. Whether you’re a developer, architect, or business user, being part of a thriving community accelerates learning, drives adoption, and sparks innovation in ways no single project team can achieve alone.

Who I Am

I’m SAP BTP DevOps & AI Manager at Bluestonex (member of the SAP AppHaus Network), a mentor guiding SAP Tech professionals at Modish Tech (my own digital brand), and a trustee for The Sanatan Parivar charity, aiming to bring communities together.

I’ve been fortunate to see SAP BTP evolve from its very beginnings, and I’m thankful to the organisations I worked for—and continue to work with—for allowing me to explore it right from when it was first introduced. 

My passion lies in bridging innovation with community impact—using technology not just to solve business challenges, but also to empower people. Over the years, I’ve seen how focusing on people first changes the trajectory of projects, communities, and careers.

If you’d like to continue the conversation or just say hello, you can find me on LinkedIn.

Now, back to the topic...

Technology Is Only Part of the Equation

SAP BTP offers incredible capabilities that reshape business operations. But these tools are only as effective as the people who imagine, build, and sustain them. Without shared understanding, collaboration, and knowledge transfer, even the most advanced solutions risk becoming underutilised—or worse, becoming that “cool proof of concept” everyone forgets about six months later.

The People-First Advantage

So what does “people first” look like in the SAP BTP journey?

  • Confidence Through Enablement – These days, enablement is the key. With an ever-changing tech stack—and especially in the SAP ecosystem, where constant branding and rebranding often push older content into the bin—newcomers are left confused about where to start. Classic example is SAP Integration Suite in the community is known by different names, CPI, IS, CI... everyone has their own version. We still refer Work Zone as the launchpad.  These are just few examples, I hear a lot from my mentees. This is why consistent enablement matters. Without it, people struggle to build confidence; with it, they can navigate the shifts, embrace the new, and grow faster.
  • Knowledge Sharing – Empowering teams through open discussions, blogs, and mentorship ensures that expertise doesn’t sit in silos. It's easy to explore technology and build a proof of concept individually. But if we multiply this, it's even more powerful. This means everyone in a team is doing it, think about the productivity and work delivered by  the team.
  • Collaboration Over Isolation – The best BTP outcomes I’ve seen came from cross-functional teams and communities working together, not from lone experts. Let's be real, you cannot do everything on your own. You need people with expertise in different areas. 
  • Innovation Through Conversation – Some of the most creative BTP use cases I’ve seen didn’t start with a specification sheet; they started with people brainstorming and challenging each other. An example of this is the SAP BTP Monitor, which the team at Bluestonex delivered when we had nothing where we can see the SAP BTP consumption. Now SAP have come up with this option in the cockpit. There are many gaps, and people at Bluestonex fill these gaps with apps, all that starts with a conversation!

Rethinking the Balance

Process and technology will always matter—but they’re accelerators, not starting points. When you put people first, you create an environment where processes can adapt and technologies can scale. Skip the people, and you risk building solutions that look great on paper but struggle in practice.

Building a Community That Lasts

That’s why community matters so much in the SAP BTP journey. Communities create ecosystems where growth is mutual—where experts share not just what they know, but also lift others to succeed. By doing so, they multiply value far beyond what technology alone can deliver.

This is why I’ve chosen to write here. My goal is to contribute to a community where knowledge flows openly and people feel empowered to innovate together. In future posts, I’ll share practical ways to accelerate BTP learning and adoption, grounded in the belief that people must always come first.

Join the Conversation

SAP BTP will continue to evolve, but one principle remains constant: people drive progress.

So, I’ll leave you with this question: In your SAP BTP journey, how have people made a difference?

Your story might be the one that inspires someone else to grow. And if nothing else, you’ll save someone from endlessly googling “Is it still called SAP Cloud Platform or…?” 😉

entry.title: Kickstart Your SAP BTP Journey
entry.content:
All you need to know and where to start

You may have come across articles, presentations, interviews or discussions about SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). You heard the term quite often, but you might still be asking:  

  • What exactly is SAP BTP?
  • Why is SAP BTP important?
  • And how do I begin exploring SAP BTP’s potential?
  • How does SAP BTP fit into the clean core strategy?

You’re now at the right place.

Whether you're a decision maker looking to drive IT strategy, an IT professional building solutions, a business user focused on innovation, or part of the academic community exploring cutting-edge technologies, this post is your launchpad into the world of SAP BTP.

Curious where you fit in? Keep reading to discover the tools, learning paths, and support SAP BTP offers for every IT role: from developers and architects to students, educators, and decision makers.

No matter your background or goals, there’s a starting point tailored just for you.

 

What We’ll Cover Here

  1. What Is SAP BTP?
  2. Why SAP BTP Matters
  3. SAP BTP and clean core
  4. Try Before You Buy: Trials & Pricing Models
  5. Real Talk: What Are Others Doing with SAP BTP?
  6. SAP BTP Essentials: Resources for Every IT Role
  7. Stay Ahead: Strategy, Roadmaps & Updates
  8. Start building today!

 

What is SAP BTP?

SAP BTP is an intuitive, modern development and innovation platform for both professional IT and business users. It is a unified platform that brings quickly together everything you need to build any idea or business vision to life, extending, and integrating existing business applications, whether they’re SAP or not.

With self-service data discovery, modeling, planning, and analytics for business users in a governed environment, it provides integration solutions to connect and streamline applications and processes across the entire enterprise, offering pre-built business content like built-in data products, integrations, workflows, app templates, and AI services.

Here’s what’s in the toolbox:

  • App Development & Automation: Rapidly develop applications or automate processes using low-code/no-code tools or opt for professional-code development when advanced customization and control are required
  • Data & Analytics: Turn your data into decisions with built-in analytics and planning tools.
  • Integration: Connect SAP or non-SAP systems like a pro.
  • Artificial Intelligence: Infuse AI into your workflows, apps, and decisions.
  • Platform Foundation: Secure, scalable, and ready for hybrid cloud environments.

Simply put, SAP BTP enables you to innovate and stay relevant by building on established foundations.

 

Why SAP BTP Matters?

Because digital transformation is not just a trend, it’s essential for adaptability and resilience, a.k.a. survival.

With SAP BTP, you can:

  • Automate repetitive tasks and free up time for real work.
  • Connect all of your systems, so they integrate.
  • Build custom apps tailored to your business needs and vision.
  • Use AI to make smarter decisions, faster.
  • Connect and harmonize all your data, eliminating data silos
  • Get mission-critical insights from your data without a background in data science

And the best part? You don’t have to start from scratch.
SAP BTP offers thousands of pre-built content packages, from application or automation templates to integration flows to dashboards to AI services.

 

SAP BTP and clean core

Clean core is a set of guiding principles that support continuous business transformation by designing agile, innovative and efficient ERP systems. The principles focus on building resilient business processes and extensions supported by seamless integration, efficient operations, and data quality.

Central to the clean core strategy are Side-by-side extensions, powered by SAP BTP.

Side-by-side extensions allow organizations to enhance their SAP landscapes without directly modifying the core SAP S/4HANA system: instead of embedding custom code within the core, new functionalities, integrations, and custom applications are developed and deployed independently on SAP BTP.

This approach leverages SAP BTP's robust services, including various runtime environments (like Cloud Foundry, Kyma, and the ABAP Environment), development tools (like SAP Business Application Studio and CAP), and critical integration services (like SAP Integration Suite and SAP Event Mesh). Connectivity is securely handled by tools like the SAP Cloud Connector for on-premise systems and the Destination Service, ensuring seamless data exchange via standard APIs and business events from the core.

Thousands of organizations, from global enterprises to emerging startups, are already leveraging SAP BTP to transform their operations. Let their success inspire you.
